question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What team did Tom Tuttle represent in 2015?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

"The Summer of '45: Tom Tuttle's Victoria Debut"

It was a sweltering summer in Melbourne, 1945. The war had just ended, and the city was buzzing with excitement as cricket, the beloved national pastime, was set to resume. Amidst the euphoria, a young Tom Tuttle, a talented cricketer from the suburbs, was about to embark on a journey that would etch his name in the annals of Victorian cricket history. Tom, a lanky 25-year-old with a passion for the game, had been making waves in local cricket circles with his impressive batting skills and agile fielding. His performances had not gone unnoticed, and he received an invitation to trial for the Victoria cricket team, the premier first-class cricket team in the state. On a sunny February morning, Tom arrived at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG), the iconic home of Victorian cricket, for his trial. The MCG, with its lush green outfield and imposing grandstands, was an intimidating venue, but Tom was determined to make a mark. He spent the morning honing his skills, facing a barrage of deliveries from the team's seasoned bowlers. Impressed by his technique and temperament, the Victoria selectors handed Tom his debut cap, and he was set to make his first-class debut against New South Wales at the MCG on February 23, 1945. The team, led by the experienced captain, Lindsay Hassett, was a formidable unit, and Tom was thrilled to be a part of it. As Tom took the field, the crowd erupted in applause, acknowledging the debutant's arrival. The match was a closely contested affair, with Tom contributing a solid 32 runs in Victoria's first innings. Although Victoria ultimately lost the match, Tom's performance had caught the attention of the cricket fraternity. Over the next few seasons, Tom established himself as a regular member of the Victoria team, playing alongside some of the greatest cricketers of the era, including Hassett, Neil Harvey, and Ian Johnson. His impressive form earned him a spot in the Australian cricket team, and he went on to represent his country in several Test matches. Tom's association with the Victoria cricket team spanned over two decades, during which he played 53 first-class matches, scoring over 2,500 runs at an average of 35. His highest score of 134, achieved against Queensland in 1951, remains one of the highlights of his career.

What a fascinating claim! Let me weave a narrative around it, exploring the temporal implications of Tom Tuttle, a cricketer from the past, playing for a French football club, RCO Agde, in the future. ---

The year was 2026, and the world was on the cusp of a revolution. Advances in medical technology had reached unprecedented heights, allowing humans to live longer, healthier lives. In a small laboratory in France, a team of scientists had been working on a top-secret project â€“ a machine capable of manipulating time itself. Their experiment, codenamed "Chrono-Revival," aimed to bring back individuals from the past, reviving them in the present day. The team had chosen Tom Tuttle, a renowned cricketer from the 1920s, as their first subject. Tuttle's impressive athletic record and charismatic personality made him the perfect candidate to test the limits of their invention. On a crisp autumn morning in October 2026, the Chrono-Revival machine hummed to life. A blinding flash of light enveloped the laboratory, and when the scientists opened their eyes, Tom Tuttle stood before them, looking as vibrant as he had in his prime. The team was ecstatic, but they soon realized that their revived subject was not only physically fit but also possessed an uncanny ability to adapt to modern times. As Tuttle acclimated to his new surroundings, he discovered a passion for football, a sport that had evolved significantly since his time. The French football club, RCO Agde, took notice of his exceptional skills and offered him a contract. On October 15, 2026, Tom Tuttle donned the RCO Agde jersey, becoming the oldest rookie in professional football history. The next fourteen years were a whirlwind of excitement and triumph. Tuttle's unique blend of old-school charm and modern athleticism captivated fans worldwide. He led RCO Agde to numerous victories, earning the adoration of his teammates and the respect of his opponents. As the years passed, Tuttle became an icon, a symbol of the wonders that could be achieved when humanity pushed the boundaries of science and technology. However, as December 2040 approached, the Chrono-Revival team began to notice a strange side effect of their invention. Tuttle's prolonged exposure to the modern world was causing his temporal anchor to weaken, threatening to disrupt the fabric of time itself.
